subject: Re: [junit] What's the best way to enhance Assert?
msgSnippet: ... If the custom assertions are used by many test cases, I ll typically use this approach: public class BaseTestCase extends TestCase { public void
messageBody:
noneofyer42businessbub wrote:

> What is the best/recommended way to add enhancements to the
> framework's
> Assert class? In other words, how does one add exta assertion
> methods (which
> are more specialized than the current ones) to the framework?
>
> A. Should one first create a sub-class of Assert then change
> TestCase's parent
> to be one's new Assert sub-class?
>
> B. Or should one tack on one's custom Assert class to exterior of
> the
> framework (i.e.-make one's custom Assert class a sub-class TestCase
> then
> make one's unit tests a sub-class of the custom Assert class)?
>

If the custom assertions are used by many test cases, I'll typically use this
approach:

public class BaseTestCase extends TestCase {

public void assertSomething(Something a, Something b) {
// ...
}

// more custom asserts
}

public class TestCaseA extends BaseTestCase {

public void testSomethingForA() {
assertSomething(a, b);
}
}

public class TestCaseB extends BaseTestCase {

public void testSomethingForB() {
assertSomething(a, b);
}
}

This works well if many test cases will end up using the custom assertion.

If the custom assertions are used in only one test case, I'll just defined
those assertions within the specialized test case itself. This gives me to
option to refactor them into a base test case later if necessary.

You could also define a separate assertion utility class with static
assertion methods, then use it with multiple test cases.
